Ketua PP Muhammadiyah: Orang Berdasi Juga Banyak yang Jahat
02 Nov 2019, 00:59 by Bunaiya Fauzi Arubone


Ketua PP Muhammadiyah: Orang Berdasi Juga Banyak yang Jahat

KBRN, Jakarta : Ketua Pimpinan Pusat (PP) Muhammadiyah, Dadang Kahmad menegaskan tidak semua wanita bercadar dan pria yang menggunakan celana cingkrang merupakan orang-orang berpaham radikal. Kebanyakan mereka justru merupakan orang-orang sholeh dan sholehah. Hal itu dia utarakan untuk mengkritisi wacana tentang pelarangan penggunaan cadar di instansi pemerintahan oleh Menteri Agama, Fachrul Razi.Menurut dia, sebagai menteri baru, mestinya Facrul Razi lebih mementingkan skala prioritas ketimbang harus mengurusi persoalan pakaian, atau cadar."Kita mengharapkan Pak Menteri (Fachrul Razi) itu lebih fokus pada hal-hal yang sangat urgent. Tentang intoleransi, pembinaan (ideologi Pancasila)," katanya saat berbincang dengan Radio Republik Indonesia, Jumat (1/11/2019).Sebab menurut dia, saat ini, utamanya sejak Pilpres 2019, persatuan Indonesia seolah-olah dalam keadaan gawat. Yang mana setiap kelompok memiliki egoisme tinggi. Hal itu ditegaskannya buruh perhatian pemerintah."Butuh perhatian kita. Jangan sampai ada yang merasa kelompok ini paling berjasa, kelompok ini kurang berjasa. Atau juga jangan sampai ada anak mas dalam kehidupan bernegara ini. Kita sama-sama mendirikan negara, sama-sama berjasa," ujarnya.Prioritas utama lainnya menurut dia yakni melawan ideologi-ideologi yang dianggap bisa membahayakan persatuan dan kesatuan bangsa, serta Pancasila."Ideologi yang membahayakan negara, membahayakan persatuan dan kesatuan," imbuhnya."Tidak semua orang yang cingkrang itu radikal. Banyak orang-orang naik, orang-orang sholeh, yang membangun bangsa ini dia berkontribusi dalam kebaikan, pakai pakaian cingkrang, mungkin soal selera saja pakaian itu," tegasnya.Karena ditekankannya, tidak semua wanita yang bercadar atau pria memakai celana cingkrang merupakan teroris, berpaham radikal atau intoleran. Lebih lanjut diakuinya, berdasarkan kajian yang mendalam, Majelis Tarjih Muhammadiyah memang pernah mengeluarkan bahwa niqab atau cadar tidak memiliki dasar dalam ajaran Islam. Namun Muhammadiyah tidak serta-merta melarang orang untuk menggunakan cadar."Kita tidak melarang dalam arti melarang orang tidak. Kalau dianjurkanlah untuk tidak pakai cadar. Kalau (Muhammadiyah) melarang itukan tidak ada hak. Itu perseorangan mereka untuk mengekspresikan keyakinannya ya," ujarnya.Hal itu karena memang menurut dia Muhammadiyah memandang bahwa cadar merupakan bentuk dari ekspresi seseorang dalam menjalankan keyakinannya."Kita itu harus tetap menghormati keyakinan orang. Karena tidak otomatis baju itu merefleksikan kejahatan," imbuhnya.Sebab tidak sedikit pula orang berdasi yang malah menjadi koruptor atau berbuat kejatahan lainnya."Orang jahat itu banyak yang berdasi, banyak yang berdasi, banyak yang pakai rok juga banyak yang jahat. Tapi kan kita tidak mendiskreditkan. Jadikan itu ekspresi identitas seseorang. Ada yang pakai rok, pakai terbuka, ada yang tertutup, ada yang tertutup sekali, itu bagian dari ekspresi orang," pungkasnya. (Foto : muhammadiyah.org.id)

All 39 people found dead in truck container were Vietnamese, British police say
02 Nov 2019, 00:21 by Associated Press 
LONDON — British police say they believe all 39 people found dead in a container truck in southeast England last week were Vietnamese nationals.
Detectives initially said the victims discovered near the port of Purfleet were from China.
Essex Police Assistant Chief Constable Tim Smith said Friday that "at this time, we believe the victims are Vietnamese nationals, and we are in contact with the Vietnamese government."
He said police think they have traced the relatives of some of the dead.
A 25-year-old man from Northern Ireland, has been charged with 39 counts of manslaughter and conspiracy to traffic people. Another man was arrested Friday in Ireland, and two others in Vietnam.
Police in Vietnam and Ireland made three new arrests Friday in the sprawling investigation.
Two people suspected of organizing a people-smuggling operation in Vietnam were arrested in Ha Tinh province following reports from 10 families there of missing relatives, VTV television reported.
Col. Nguyen Tien Nam, deputy chief of Ha Tinh provincial police, was quoted as saying the suspects were directly involved in the case in which people paid smugglers to be taken to England and are now feared to be among the bodies found in the container.
Police said the suspects have been organizing people smuggling in the area for several years.
In Ireland, a 22-year-old man was arrested in connection with the Oct. 23 discovery of the bodies in what appears to have been a botched people-smuggling operation. Essex police in Britain, who issued the European Arrest Warrant on which he was arrested, started extradition proceedings to bring him to the U.K. to face charges of manslaughter.
A spokesman for the Dublin High Court said Eamonn Harrison, of Newry in Northern Ireland, appeared in court Friday. He was ordered detained until a hearing on Nov. 11.
The investigation is gathering speed, but authorities have thus far been unable to identify the victims or say exactly where they came from.
Police initially said the victims were from China, but the focus shifted to Vietnam when families there reported that they had not heard from loved ones who were in transit at the time.
In Britain, police have charged 25-year-old Maurice Robinson, also from Northern Ireland, with 39 counts of manslaughter and conspiracy to traffic people. They say he drove the cab of the truck to an English port, where it picked up the container, which had arrived by ferry from Zeebrugge in Belgium.
British officials have stepped up patrols in Purfleet, the English port where the container came in by ferry. They have announced an agreement with Belgium to allow more British immigration officers to be based in Zeebrugge.
British police on Friday asked two other suspects, Ronan and Christopher Hughes, to turn themselves in.
Police say they have already spoken to Ronan Hughes by telephone but want to talk to the two in person.
